headline: Ukraine conflict: Ohio politicos push Russian divestment, OSU cancels food delivery robots
author: Laura A. Bischoff
sentences: "As Russian aggression continues to intensify against the people of Ukraine, I want to assure Ohioans that our state has no contracts with Russian businesses now, and will not have any contracts for goods and services going forward," Gov.

In a related move, state leaders asked Ohio's five public pension systems and the Bureau of Workers' Compensation, which combined have roughly $280 billion invested, to immediately divest from Russian companies.

Laura Bischoff is a reporter for the USA TODAY Network Ohio Bureau, which serves the Columbus Dispatch, Cincinnati Enquirer, Akron Beacon Journal and 18 other affiliated news organizations across Ohio.
On Thursday, the governor issued an executive order telling all state agencies, universities and pension funds to divest investments and cancel contracts with Russian companies.
"One of Ohio’s retirement systems has approximately $112 million in Russian investments; I’m sure others have significant holdings," Yost said in a letter sent Wednesday.
Ohio State University will pull the plug on robots that deliver meals for GrubHub on campus after the meal service ended its partnership with Russia-based Yandex SDG.
We are in the process of ceasing the rover delivery option after completing any deliveries that are currently out on campus," the university said in a statement.
Grubhub had contracted with Yandex to provide about cooler-sized robots to deliver meals on more than 250 college campuses, including Ohio State University.
Ohio Attorney General Dave Yost told the pension fund directors they have a "moral imperative" to divest and punish Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.
He directed the Ohio BWC, the state insurance fund for injured workers, to divest any of its $28 billion portfolio from Russian interests.
Ohio Police & Fire Pension Fund said it holds $6.5 million, or 0.3% of its total $19 billion portfolio, in Russian investments.
The Ohio Public Employees Retirement System, the largest in the state, is currently calculating its total assets in Russia.
The pension funds have a fiduciary responsibility to manage investments in the best interest of their members.
"Ohio State affirms and supports GrubHub’s decision to end their partnership with Yandex.

It is unclear how much of that may be in Russian companies.
Combined, the funds have more than $250 billion invested.
"We will not support Russia with Ohio taxpayer dollars."
He did not specify which fund holds that amount.
Mike DeWine said in a statement.
